definitions: take money from someone through deception or overcharging them unfairly
move the castle piece in chess in a straight horizontal or vertical line
examples: The tourist felt he was rooked by the street vendor
Don't let that shop rook you with inflated prices
She decided to rook her king to safety first
He rooked from a8 to a1 in one move

definitions: rent and occupy a room as a place to live temporarily
share a room or apartment with another person as roommates
examples: He rooms at a boarding house near the university
She decided to room downtown while working there
They roomed together during their college years happily
Would you like to room with me next semester?

definitions: settle on a perch or branch for rest or sleep as birds do
settle oneself in a place for an extended period of time
examples: The chickens roost in the barn every evening naturally
Wild turkeys roost high in trees for safety overnight
He decided to roost at his friend's place temporarily
Problems tend to roost where you least expect them

definitions: develop and send out roots into soil as a plant grows
search through something by moving things around looking for something specific
cheer for and actively support a team or person in competition
establish something firmly and deeply in a place or situation
examples: The cutting should root within two weeks in water
These plants root quickly in moist soil during spring
She rooted through her bag looking for her keys
The pig rooted around in the mud for food
The crowd rooted loudly for the home team yesterday
I'll always root for you no matter what happens
Democracy slowly rooted itself in the nation's consciousness
Bad habits can root themselves deeply over many years

definitions: fasten or secure something using rope or similar strong cord material
catch an animal by throwing a lasso or rope around it
persuade someone to take part in an activity they may be reluctant about
examples: They roped the cargo securely to the truck bed
The climber carefully roped himself to the mountain face
The cowboy roped the calf in just eight seconds
She learned to rope cattle during her summer vacation
They roped me into helping with the charity event
Don't let him rope you into his crazy schemes

definitions: rub rosin on a bow or surface to increase friction and improve grip
examples: The violinist rosined her bow before the performance began
You should rosin your bow regularly for best sound

definitions: decompose through natural biological processes becoming soft and unusable
gradually deteriorate in quality or condition through neglect or inactivity
examples: The fallen apples will rot if left on the ground
Wood rots quickly in damp conditions without proper treatment
His skills began to rot after years without practice
The abandoned building rotted away over several decades slowly

definitions: move in a circular motion around a central point or axis
take turns in a position or duty in regular succession
plant different crops in succession on the same land to maintain fertility
examples: The Earth rotates on its axis once every day
Slowly rotate the handle clockwise to open the valve
The guards rotate shifts every eight hours without fail
We rotate hosting duties among all the family members
Farmers rotate crops to keep the soil healthy naturally
They rotate corn and soybeans in their fields annually

definitions: apply red cosmetic coloring to the cheeks or lips for decoration
examples: She rouged her cheeks lightly before the photo shoot
Actors rouge their faces heavily for stage performances

definitions: make a surface uneven or coarse through abrasion or damage
live without usual comforts or conveniences especially when camping or traveling
create a preliminary sketch or draft without attention to detail
handle someone in a violent or aggressive physical manner
examples: The sandpaper will rough the surface for better adhesion
Years of use had roughed the wooden handle considerably
They decided to rough it in the wilderness for weeks
We roughed it without electricity during the storm
She roughed out the design on paper before painting
Let me rough in the basic shapes first quickly
The gang roughed him up in the alley last night
Don't rough the kids around when you're playing

definitions: shape something into a round or curved form by cutting or molding
travel around something following its edge or perimeter
gather people or animals together into a group or enclosure
bring something to completion by adding final elements or adjustments
examples: The carpenter rounded the edges of the table carefully
She rounded the corners of the paper with scissors
The ship will round the cape during tomorrow's voyage
They rounded the bend at high speed dangerously
Cowboys rounded up the cattle before the storm arrived
Police rounded up suspects throughout the entire neighborhood
Let's round off the meeting with final questions
She rounded out her education with practical experience

definitions: wake someone from sleep or make them become alert and active
stimulate someone to take action or become actively involved in something
evoke or provoke strong feelings or emotional responses in someone
examples: The alarm clock roused her at dawn every morning
It's difficult to rouse teenagers on weekend mornings
The speech roused the crowd to immediate action yesterday
His words roused the team to play their best
The movie roused feelings of nostalgia in older viewers
The injustice roused anger throughout the entire community

definitions: defeat an enemy or opponent completely in battle or competition
force someone to retreat in disorder after overwhelming defeat
search for something by turning things over or digging around
examples: The home team routed their rivals forty to seven
Napoleon's army was routed at Waterloo in eighteen fifteen
Enemy forces routed the defenders from their positions quickly
The surprise attack routed them in complete chaos
Pigs rout in the soil searching for food daily
She routed through old boxes in the dusty attic

definitions: send or direct something or someone along a particular path or course
plan and determine the path or course for travel or delivery
examples: They routed the package through Memphis for faster delivery
Please route all calls to my mobile phone today
We need to route our journey through scenic mountain roads
The GPS automatically routes you around heavy traffic

definitions: move about aimlessly without fixed destination or purpose
travel extensively through an area exploring different places
examples: The dog roved through the neighborhood looking for food
His eyes roved around the room nervously during questioning
They roved across Europe for months without any plans
Nomads have roved these lands for countless generations

definitions: move a boat through water using oars in coordinated strokes
arrange objects or people in straight horizontal lines
examples: They rowed across the lake in under an hour
She rows every morning for exercise on the river
The farmer rowed the corn seeds precisely in the field
Students were rowed up for the class photo

definitions: move something against a surface with pressure and friction repeatedly
apply a substance to a surface by moving it with pressure
cause soreness or irritation through repeated contact or friction
examples: She rubbed her hands together to warm them quickly
The cat rubbed against my leg affectionately this morning
Rub the ointment gently into the affected area twice daily
He rubbed sunscreen on his face before going outside
These new shoes rub my heels painfully when walking
The rope rubbed his wrists raw during the escape

definitions: cover or coat something with rubber material for protection or waterproofing
examples: They rubbered the fabric to make it completely waterproof
The manufacturer rubbers all electrical wires for safety

definitions: criticize or condemn something severely as being of poor quality
reject or dismiss something as having no value or merit
examples: Critics rubbished the film despite its commercial success
Don't rubbish her ideas without considering them first
He rubbished the proposal as completely impractical yesterday
The committee rubbished all suggestions for budget increases

definitions: classify or organize something according to established categories or criteria
examples: Teachers rubric student essays using standardized assessment criteria
The committee will rubric proposals based on innovation

definitions: form into wrinkles or folds in fabric through movement or pressure
compete for possession of the ball in rugby after a tackle
examples: Her dress rucked up as she sat down awkwardly
The carpet tends to ruck under heavy foot traffic
The forwards rucked fiercely for possession near the tryline
Players must ruck legally without using their hands

definitions: feel deep regret or sorrow about something that has happened or been done
examples: He will rue the day he betrayed his friends
She rued her hasty decision to quit her job

definitions: play a trump card when unable to follow suit in card games
examples: She ruffed with the ace of spades brilliantly
You can ruff if you have no clubs left

definitions: cause complete destruction or devastation to a building or structure
cause someone to lose all their money or financial stability
completely spoil or damage something beyond repair or usefulness
examples: The earthquake ruined hundreds of homes in the city
Years of neglect had ruined the historic mansion completely
Bad investments ruined him financially within just two years
The scandal ruined several prominent business leaders overnight
The rain ruined our picnic plans for the weekend
One mistake ruined her chances of winning the competition

definitions: exercise ultimate authority or power over a country or group
make an official legal decision or judgment about a matter
mark paper with straight parallel lines using a ruler or guide
examples: The king ruled the nation for over forty years
She rules the company with wisdom and fairness
The judge ruled in favor of the plaintiff yesterday
The committee will rule on the matter next week
Students ruled their notebooks before beginning to write neatly
Rule the paper into columns for your data

definitions: perform the rumba dance with its characteristic hip movements and rhythm
examples: They learned to rumba during their Caribbean vacation
The couple rumbaed gracefully across the dance floor

definitions: make a continuous deep resonant sound like distant thunder
move along while making a deep continuous vibrating sound
engage in a gang fight or street brawl between rival groups
examples: Thunder rumbled ominously in the distance all afternoon
His stomach rumbled loudly during the quiet exam
The old truck rumbled down the country road slowly
Tanks rumbled through the city streets at dawn
The two gangs rumbled in the abandoned warehouse
They used to rumble over territory in the neighborhood

definitions: circulate information as unverified gossip or speculation about someone or something
examples: It was rumored that the company would merge soon
People rumor all sorts of things without any proof

definitions: circulate information as unverified gossip or speculation about someone or something
examples: It was rumoured that she would resign next month
They rumoured his involvement without any evidence whatsoever

definitions: move at a speed faster than walking by taking quick steps
function or operate as a machine or system is designed to
be in charge of and manage a business or organization
extend in a particular direction or continue for a specific duration
flow continuously as a liquid moves through or from something
compete as a candidate for an elected position or office
examples: She runs five miles every morning before breakfast
The children ran excitedly toward the playground
This computer runs much faster than my old one
The engine runs smoothly after the recent tune-up
He successfully runs three restaurants in the city
She has run the company for over ten years
The road runs parallel to the river for miles
The play will run for six weeks on Broadway
Water runs through these old pipes into the tank
The tap has been running all day long
She decided to run for mayor this year
He ran against the incumbent in the last election

definitions: break or burst suddenly under pressure or strain
cause something to break or burst open suddenly and violently
examples: The pipe ruptured during the freezing weather last night
His appendix ruptured before he could reach the hospital
The explosion ruptured the gas main causing widespread damage
Heavy lifting can rupture abdominal muscles if done improperly

definitions: move or act with urgent haste toward a destination or goal
make a sudden assault or charge against an enemy position
do something too quickly without proper care or consideration
examples: She rushed to catch the last train home tonight
Don't rush through the intersection without looking carefully
The soldiers rushed the enemy position at dawn
Protesters rushed the stage during the speech
They rushed the project and made several costly mistakes
Don't rush your decision about such an important matter

definitions: become covered with rust through oxidation of iron or steel
deteriorate through lack of use or practice over time
examples: The old car rusted badly in the salty coastal air
Iron gates rust quickly without protective paint
His language skills rusted after years abroad without practice
Musical abilities rust without regular practice and performance

definitions: create deep grooves or furrows in a surface through repeated use
engage in mating behavior during breeding season as deer do
examples: Heavy trucks rutted the dirt road during rainy season
Years of traffic had rutted the old forest path
The stags rut aggressively during autumn mating season
Male deer rut from September through November typically

definitions: strike or cut with a saber sword in combat or practice
examples: The cavalry officer sabered through the enemy line
Fencers saber according to strict competition rules

definitions: deliberately destroy or damage equipment or property to disrupt operations
deliberately obstruct or undermine a plan or effort to prevent success
examples: Enemy agents sabotaged the railway bridge during the war
Workers sabotaged machinery to protest unsafe working conditions
Someone deliberately sabotaged our presentation by deleting files
He sabotaged his own chances by arriving late

definitions: strike or cut with a sabre sword in combat or practice
examples: The hussar sabred his way through the battlefield
Olympic fencers sabre with lightweight flexible blades

definitions: dismiss someone from employment abruptly and often without warning
violently plunder and destroy a captured town or city
tackle the quarterback behind the line of scrimmage in football
examples: The company sacked half its workforce during the recession
He was sacked for repeatedly arriving late to work
The invading army sacked the city after a long siege
Vikings sacked monasteries along the coast for treasure
The defender sacked the quarterback for a ten-yard loss
He's been sacked twelve times this season already

definitions: give up something valuable for the sake of something more important
offer something to a deity as an act of worship or propitiation
deliberately make an out to advance a runner in baseball
examples: She sacrificed her career to care for her parents
They sacrificed comfort for the chance at adventure
Ancient peoples sacrificed animals to appease their gods
The priest sacrificed a lamb during the ceremony
He sacrificed to move the runner to third base
The batter sacrificed with a perfect bunt

definitions: put a saddle on a horse or other animal for riding
burden someone with an onerous responsibility or difficult task
examples: She saddled her horse quickly for the morning ride
The cowboy saddled up at dawn every day
They saddled him with all the blame unfairly
Don't saddle me with your problems right now

definitions: protect something or someone from harm or damage through preventive measures
examples: New laws safeguard consumers from fraudulent business practices
We must safeguard our children's future through education

definitions: sink or bend downward under weight or pressure or from weakness
decline in strength or vigor or lose momentum
examples: The old roof sagged dangerously under the snow's weight
Her shoulders sagged with exhaustion after the long day
Sales sagged during the economic downturn last quarter
Their spirits sagged when they heard the bad news

definitions: travel in a boat using sails to catch the wind
move smoothly and rapidly with apparent ease through air or space
begin a voyage by ship departing from a port
examples: They sailed across the Atlantic in forty days
She learned to sail at summer camp last year
The ball sailed over the fence for a home run
Papers sailed off the desk in the strong wind
The cruise ship sails at midnight from Miami
We sail for Europe on Tuesday morning

definitions: officially declare a deceased person to be a saint in the church
examples: The Pope will saint the missionary next year
She was sainted centuries after her death

definitions: add salt to food for flavor or seasoning
preserve food by treating it with salt to prevent spoilage
examples: Salt the pasta water generously before adding the noodles
She salted the soup to enhance its flavor
Fishermen salt their catch to preserve it longer
They salted meat for the long winter months

definitions: give a formal military sign of respect by raising hand to head
express respect or admiration for someone's achievements or qualities
examples: Soldiers must salute their superior officers when meeting
The guard saluted as the general passed by
We salute your courage in difficult circumstances
The nation salutes its fallen heroes every year

definitions: rescue a wrecked or disabled ship or its cargo from loss
extract and save usable parts or materials from damaged items
examples: Divers salvaged treasure from the sunken Spanish galleon
The crew salvaged what they could from the wreck
We salvaged parts from the old computer for reuse
They salvaged timber from the demolished building

definitions: soothe wounded feelings or ease guilty conscience with comforting words
examples: She tried to salve his hurt pride with compliments
Nothing could salve their grief after the tragedy

definitions: perform the Brazilian samba dance with its characteristic rhythmic movements
examples: They learned to samba during Carnival in Rio
The dancers sambaed energetically across the stage

definitions: test or examine a small amount of something to assess quality
experience or try something briefly to get an impression of it
examples: The quality inspector samples products from each batch daily
Scientists sample the water monthly for contamination levels
Visitors can sample local cuisine at the food festival
She sampled several careers before finding her passion
